title-group.article-title: Acylated pelargonidin glycosides from the red-purple flowers of Iberis umbellata L. and the red flowers of Erysimum × cheiri (L.) Crantz (Brassicaceae)

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Fumi Tatsuzawa
Faculty of Agriculture, Iwate University, Morioka 020-8550, Japan
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Erysimum × cheiri
(L.) Crantz.
Iberis umbellata
L. Brassicaceae Acylated pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5- glucoside Acylated pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5- glucoside Ferulic acid Malonic acid p -Coumaric acid Sinapic acid
A B S T R A C T

Five previously undescribed acylated pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucosides (pigments 2–6) were isolated from the red-purple flowers of
Iberis umbellata
L. ‘Candycane Rose’ and ‘Candycane Red’, in addition to a known one (pigment 1). The structures of five undescribed acylated anthocyanins were determined by chemical and spectroscopic methods to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-(“acyl-A”)-β-glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(“acyl-B”)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-[6-
O
-(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside], in which the “acyl-A” group was either trans -sinapic (2), trans -ferulic (3), trans -sinapic (4), trans -ferulic (5), or trans -ferulic acid (6), and “acyl-B” was either glucosyltrans -p -coumaric acid (2), glucosyl- trans -p -coumaric acid (3), trans -feruloyl-glucosyl- trans -p -coumaric acid (4), trans -feruloyl-glucosyl- trans -p -coumaric acid (5), or glucosyl- trans -feruloyl-glucosyl- trans -p -coumaric acid (6). Moreover, three previously undescribed acylated pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides (pigments 7, 8, and 10) and one undescribed acylated pelargonidin 3-(3 X -glucosylsambubioside)-5-glucoside (pigment 9) were isolated from the red flowers of
Erysimum × cheiri
(L.) Crantz ‘Aurora’ as major anthocyanins. The structures of the three undescribed acylated pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides were determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-(“acyl-C”)-β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(“acyl-D”)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside), in which the “acyl-C” group was either non (7), non (8), or trans -p -coumaric acid (10) and “acyl-D” was either trans -p - coumaric (7), trans -ferulic (8), or trans -p -coumaric acid (10). Moreover, a previously undescribed acylated pelargonidin 3-(3 X -glucosylsambubioside)-5-glucoside was identified to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -p - coumaroyl)-3-
O
-(β-glucopyranosyl)-β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside) (9). In addition, the distribution of anthocyanidins structural elements in 24 Brassicaceous species is compared.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 1. Introduction

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Iberis umbellata L
. ( Brassicaceae ), the common candytuft, is an annual flowering plant species, native to southern Europe that usually is cultivated as a popular annual garden plant with white, pink, red, purple, or purple-violet flowers.
Erysimum × cheiri (L.) Crantz
( Brassicaceae ), the common wallflower, is a perennial subshrub species, native to southern Europe that usually is cultivated as a popular biennial garden plant with yellow, orange, red, or red-purple flowers. As part of the ongoing work on flower and/or root color variation due to acylated anthocyanins in olericultural and floricultural plants in the Brassicaceae , I and my co-workers previously reported the isolation of 75 acylated anthocyanins from the flowers of plants in the family Brassicaceae , including 11 acylated cyanidin 3-sophoroside-5- glucosides in the purple-violet flowers of
I . umbellata
cultivars and two acylated cyanidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides in the red and orange-red E-mail address: fumi@iwate-u.ac.jp. flowers of
E. × cheiri
cultivars (
;
;
,
, 2008, 2011; Tatsuzawa, 2012, 2014a, b, 2016;
,
,
, b, 2010a, 2012a, b, c, 2013, 2014, 2015a, b, 2016, 2018). Sophorose is a disaccharide composed of two glucopyranose residues, with the glucoside attached in β configuration at the 2 position of the reducing glucose. A sophoroside means this sugar attached with a glycosidic bond in β configuration, i.e. 2-
O
-β-glucopyranosyl-β-glucopyranoside. Sambubiose is a quite similar disaccharide but with the outermost glucoside replaced by a xyloside, i.e. 2-
O
-β-xylopyranosyl-βglucopyranoside. In essence, a sambubioside lacks the hydroxymethyl group of C 6 in glucose, but is otherwise identical to a sophoroside. Herein, I report the structural elucidation of 9 undescribed acylated pelargonidin glycosides, along with a known one, from the red-purple flowers of
I . umbellata ‘Candycane
Red’ and ‘Candycane Rose’ and the red flowers of
E. × cheiri
‘Aurora’
2. Results

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: https://doi.org/ 10.1016/j.phytochem.2018.12.010

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Received 7 September 2018 ; Received in revised form 25 November 2018 ; Accepted 16 December 2018

mixed-citation.named-content: Acylated pelargonidin glycosides from the red-purple flowers of Iberis umbellata L. and the red flowers of Erysimum × cheiri (L.) Crantz (Brassicaceae)

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature: 2.1. Anthocyanins in the red-purple flowers of I. umbellata

tp:treatment-sec.p:
By HPLC analysis of an extract from the red-purple flowers of
Iberis umbellata
, I identified more than 20 anthocyanin peaks. Among these peaks, six major anthocyanin peaks were isolated from the flowers of ‘Candycane Red’ (
) and ‘Candycane Rose’ by extraction by 5% HOAc, and purified according to the procedure described previously ( Saito et al., 2008 ). The same six pigments were found in both cultivars, but the profiles differed slightly. Percentages of total anthocyanin contents based on HPLC peak aerias at 530 nm are as follows for the two cultivars: ‘Candycane Red’: 1 : 4.0%, 2 : 5.8%, 3 : 8.0%, 4 : 10.3%, 5 : 15.9%, 6 : 7.6%; ‘Candycane Rose’ 1 : 5.6%, 2 : 13.4%, 3 : 6.9%, 4 : 9.6%, 5 : 6.9%, 6 : 8.3%. The chromatographic and spectroscopic properties of these pigments are summarized in Experimental. Visible maxima ( λ max ) from UV–VIS spectra of
1–6 in
0.1% HCl-MeOH were observed at 508–519 nm . In addition, the ratio of absorbance at 440 nm relative to the visible maximum ( E 440 / E vis.max ) were 0.17–0.20. With the addition of AlCl 3 , 1–6 did not exhibit a bathochromic shift, indicating that they lacked a vicinal hydroxyl group in the B-ring. Therefore, these initial data suggest that 1–6 may have a pelargonidin 3,5-glycosyl type structure ( Tatsuzawa and Shinoda, 2005 ). This was subsequently confirmed by the NMR analysis. The ratio of E acyl / E vis.max was 0.90–1.63 suggesting that they had one, two or three hydroxycinnamic acid units ( Saito et al., 2008 ) which was also confirmed in the subsequent NMR analysis. Pigment 1 was identified by HR-FAB MS (calc. for C 45 H 49 O 25 requires: 989.2563. Found: 989.2556) and comparison of HPLC, TLC, and UV–Vis data (see section 4.3.1) with pelargonidin 3- O -[2- O -(β-glucopyranosyl)-6- O -( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5- O -[6- O -(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside] obtained from
Raphanus sativus ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2008b )
(
,
).

From all pigments 2–6 ( ca . 1 mg each), the same deacyl anthocyanin was obtained from the alkaline hydrolysis (see section 4.4.). These were identified to be pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucoside by direct comparison of HPLC behavior with those of authentic samples obtained from
Raphanus sativus ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2008b )
. 4- O -glucosyl-ferulic acid, 4- O -glucosyl- p -coumaric acid, and ferulic acid ( Saito et al., 2008 ), 4- O -glucosyl- p -coumaric acid and ferulic acid, 4- O -glucosyl- p -coumaric acid and sinapic acid, and 4- O -glucosyl- p -coumaric acid, ferulic acid, and sinapic acid were obtained from the alkaline hydrolysate of pigment 6 , pigments 3 and 5 , pigment 2 , and pigment 4 , respectively, and they were identified by comparison of HPLC behavior with those of authentic samples obtained from a purple-violet cultivar of
I. umbellata
using the same process as for alkaline hydrolysis ( Saito et al., 2008 ).

Elemental components of 2–6 were confirmed by measuring their high resolution FAB mass spectra (HR-FAB MS) (LMS-700, JEOL Ltd.). To obtain information on the linkages among the aglycone, sugars, and/ or acids as well as to investigate the structural similarity of these pigments, partial hydrolysis (see section 4.5.) of 1–6 was carried with a procedure described previously ( Saito et al., 2008 ). Pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucoside was detected in the hydrolysates as intermediary pigment products. The intermediate was confirmed by comparing HPLC results to those of authentic deacylated anthocyanin obtained from
Raphanus sativus ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2008b )
. Pigment 1 was in the hydrolysate as one of the intermediary pigment products from pigments 2–6 . The pigments 1 , 3 , and 5 were detected in the hydrolysate of 6 as intermediary pigment products. Similarly, 1 and 3 were detected in the hydrolysate of 5 . Pigments 1 and 2 were detected in the hydrolysate of 4 . Moreover, pigment 1 was detected in the hydrolysate of 2 and 3 . From these results, the structures of 2–6 were presumed to be based on pigment 1 . The structures of 2–6 were elucidated further based on analyses of their 1 H (400 MHz), 13 C (100 MHz) and 2D (COSY, NOESY, 1 H- 13 C HMQC, and 1 H- 13 C HMBC) NMR (JNM AL-400, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo , Japan ) spectra in CF 3 COOD-DMSO‑ d 6 (1:9) with TMS as an internal standard.

sec.title: 2.1.1. Pigment 2
sec.p:
The elemental components of pigment 2 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 62 H 69 O 34 requires: 1357.3670. Found: 1357.3685. This value indicated that pigment 2 was composed of pigment 1 with one additional residue each of a hexose and sinapic acid. The structure of pigment 2 was elucidated further based on analysis of its 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra ( Table 1 ). The 1 H NMR spectrum (400 MHz in CF 3 CO 2 D-DMSO‑ d 6 , 1:9) of pigment 2 exhibited seven aromatic protons that were identified as containing a pelargonidin moiety. The anomeric protons of sugar moieties were assigned at δ 5.71 ( d , J = 7.6 Hz, H-1 of Glc A), 5.21 ( d , J = 7.6 Hz, H-1 of Glc B), 5.30 ( d , J = 8.0 Hz, H-1 of Glc C ), and 4.97 ( d , J = 7.3 Hz, H-1 of Glc D), and those glucose moieties of Glc A, B, C , and D were determined to be in the β-glucopyranose form based on their observed J values ( Table 1 ). By application of the NOESY experiment, NOEs between H-1 of Glc A and H-4 (δ8.82) of pelargonidin, H-1 of Glc B and H-6 (δ7.00) of pelargonidin, H-2 (δ4.19) of Glc A and H-1 of Glc C , and H-3′,5′ of p -coumaric acid ( I ) (δ6.99) and H-1 of Glc D were observed ( Fig. 2 ). These findings suggest that OH-3 and OH-5 of pelargonidin are glycosylated with Glc A and Glc B, respectively, such that OH-2 of Glc A is bonded with Glc C forming sophorose, and OH-4 of p -coumaric acid ( I ) bonds with Glc D to form 4-
O
-glucosyl- p -coumaric acid. The characteristic five protons shifted to the lower magnetic fields were assigned to two methylenes (H-6a and b) of Glc A (δ4.30 and 4.42) and Glc B (δ4.15 and 4.39), and H-2 of Glc C (δ4.72) ( Table 1 ). These results revealed that the OH-6 of Glc A and Glc B, and H-2 of Glc C were acylated by three acylated residues ( p -coumaric, malonic, or sinapic acid). Moreover, weak NOEs between H-6a and b of Glc A and H-2′,6′ (δ7.43) of p -coumaric acid ( I ) and H-2 of Glc C and H-2′,6′ (δ6.98) of sinapic acid (III) were observed ( Fig. 2 ) suggesting that OH-6 of Glc A and OH-2 of Glc C were acylated with p -coumaric acid ( I ) and sinapic acid (III), respectively. The olefinic proton signals of p -coumaric acid ( I ) (δ6.35, d , J = 15.9 Hz and 7.41, d , J = 15.9 Hz) and sinapic acid (III) (δ6.51, d , J = 15.9 Hz and 7.54, d , J = 15.9 Hz) exhibited large coupling constants in accordance with the acid having trans configuration.

Overall, these results indicate that pigment 2 was the pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-O-( trans -sinapoyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(4-
O
-(β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-[6-
O
-(malonyl)- β-glucopyranoside] ( Fig. 2 , Fig. S1 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was further confirmed by the measurement of its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ).

sec.title: 2.1.2. Pigment 3
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 3 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 61 H 67 O 33 requires: 1327.3565. Found: 1327.3516. This value indicated that pigment 2 was composed of pigment 1 with one additional residue each of a hexose and ferulic acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 3 was similar to that of pigment 2 except for the signals of sinapic acid (III) that were replaced by signals of ferulic acid (III). The three aromatic proton signals of ferulic acid (III) were observed at δ7.26 (H-2), 6.83 (H-5), and 7.09 (H-6) and contained large coupling constants ( J = 15.9 and 15.9 Hz) of olefinic proton signals (δ6.45 Hα and 7.53 H-β), which indicates a trans -ferulic acid ( Table 1 ). From these results, pigment 3 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-O-( trans - feruloyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(4-
O
-(β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -p -coumaroyl)- β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-[6-
O
-(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside] ( Fig. 2 , Fig. S1 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by the measurement of its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ).

sec.title: 2.1.3. Pigment 4
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 4 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 72 H 77 O 37 requires: 1533.4144. Found: 1533.4169. This value indicated that pigment 4 was composed of pigment 1 with one additional residue each of a hexose, ferulic acid, and sinapic acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 4 was identical to that of pigment 2 , except for the Glc D moiety and an additional ferulic acid (II) moiety. By analysis of the 2D COSY spectrum, it was revealed that OH-6 of Glc D was acylated with a ferulic acid, since the H-6a and b signals of Glc D were shifted to a lower field at δ4.24 and 4.46. The three additional aromatic proton signals of ferulic acid (II) were observed at δ7.22 (H-2), 6.72 (H-5), and 6.92 (H-6) with large coupling constants ( J = 15.9 and 15.9 Hz) of olefinic proton signals (δ6.42 H-α and 7.47 H-β) indicating a trans -ferulic acid ( Table 1 ).

From these results, pigment 4 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -sinapoyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(4-
O
-(6-( trans -feruloyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
- [6-
O
-(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside] ( Fig. 2 , Fig. S1 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by measuring its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ).

sec.title: 2.1.4. Pigment 5
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 5 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 71 H 75 O 36 requires: 1503.4038. Found: 1503.4011. This value indicated that pigment 2 was composed of pigment 1 with one additional residue of a hexose and two additional residues of ferulic acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 5 was similar to that of pigment 4 except for the signals of sinapic acid (III) that were replaced by signals of ferulic acid (III). The three aromatic proton signals of ferulic acid (III) were observed at δ7.27 (H-2), 6.82 (H-5), and 7.10 (H-6) with large coupling constants ( J = 15.9 and 15.9 Hz) of olefinic proton signals (δ6.46 H-α and 7.52 H-β), indicating a trans -ferulic acid ( Table 1 ). From these results, pigment 5 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -feruloyl)-β -glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(4-
O
-(6-( trans -feruloyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-[6-
O
-(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside] ( Fig. 2 , Fig. S1 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by measuring its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ).

sec.title: 2.1.5. Pigment 6
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 6 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 77 H 85 O 41 requires: 1665.4566. Found: 1665.4504. This value indicated that pigment 6 was composed of pigment 1 with two additional residues each of hexose and ferulic acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 6 was identical to that of pigment 5 , except for the additional signals of a Glc E moiety. The anomeric proton Glc E was assigned at δ5.04 ( d , J = 7.6 Hz), and its coupling constants suggested Glc E to be β-glucopyranose ( Table 1 ). By analyzing of its NOESY spectrum, a strong NOE signal was observed between the signals of H-5 of ferulic acid (II) and H-1 of Glc E , indicating that Glc E was attached to the OH-4 of ferulic acid (II) through a glycosidic bond.

Therefore, structure of pigment 6 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -feruloyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)-6-
O
-(4-
O
-(6-
O
- (4-
O
-(β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -feruloyl)-β-glucopyranosyl)- trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-[6-
O
-(malonyl)-β-glucopyranoside] ( Fig. 2 , Fig. S1 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by measuring its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 1 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Exchangeable.

mixed-citation.named-content: Acylated pelargonidin glycosides from the red-purple flowers of Iberis umbellata L. and the red flowers of Erysimum × cheiri (L.) Crantz (Brassicaceae)

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature: 2.2. Anthocyanins in the red flowers of E. × cheiri

tp:treatment-sec.p:
By HPLC analysis, four major anthocyanin peaks were detected in the 5% HOAc extract from the red flowers of
E. × cheiri
‘Aurora’ (
). Percentages of the total anthocyanin contents based on HPLC peak areas at 530 nm are as follows: 7 : 52.6%, 8 : 7.5%, 9 : 15.7%, 10 : 14.4%. These anthocyanins ( 7–10 ) were isolated from the dried flowers and purified according to procedures described previously ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2006 ). The chromatographic and spectroscopic properties of these pigments are summarized in Experimental. Visible maxima ( λ max ) in 0.1% HCl-MeOH were observed at 509–510 nm . In addition, ( E 440 / E vis.max ) ratios were 0.22–0.23. Addition of AlCl 3 did not exhibit a bathochromic shift, indicating that these pigments lack a vicinal hydroxyl group in the B-ring. Therefore, these data suggested that 7–10 may have a pelargonidin 3,5-glycosyl type structure ( Tatsuzawa and Shinoda, 2005 ). The E acyl / E vis.max ratio 0.83–1.41 suggested that 7–10 had one or two hydroxycinnamic acid units ( Saito et al., 2008 ). Alkaline hydrolysis of 1 mg of each pigment yielded deacyl anthocyanins and hydroxycinnamic acids. The structure of the deacyl anthocyanin of pigments 7 , 8 , and 10 was identified as pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5- glucoside by direct comparison of HPLC behavior with those of authentic samples obtained from
Lobularia maritima (Tatsuzawa et al., 2010a)
. The structure of the deacyl anthocyanin of pigment 9 was not identified at this stage. p -Coumaric acid was obtained from the alkaline hydrolysate of pigments 7 , 9 , and 10 , but ferulic acid was obtained from the alkaline hydrolysate of pigment 8 based on comparison to authentic samples (Wako Pure chemical Industries. Ltd., Osaka , Japan ). The structures of 7–10 were elucidated further as described below based on analysis of their NMR spectra in CF 3 COOD-DMSO‑ d 6 (1:9), with TMS as an internal standard.

sec.title: 2.2.1. Pigment 7
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 7 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 41 H 45 O 21 requires: 873.2453. Found: 873.2466. This value indicated that pigment 7 was composed pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucoside with one additional residue of p - coumaric acid.

The chemical shifts of the 11 aromatic protons of pelargonidin and p -coumaric acid moieties with their coupling constants were assigned as shown in Table 2. A pair of doublet resonances, assigned to the two olefinic proton signals of the p -coumaric acid moiety indicate a trans configuration for the acids based on their coupling constants ( J = 15.9 Hz each) ( Table 2 ). The chemical shifts of the sugar moiety protons were observed in the region of δ3.12–5.72, with the three anomeric proton resonances at δ5.72 ( d , J = 7.6 Hz, Glc A), 5.11 ( d , J = 7.8 Hz, Glc B), and 4.81 ( d , J = 7.8 Hz, Xyl). Based on the observed coupling constants ( Table 2 ), these three sugars were assumed to be in the β-pyranose forms. The linkages and/or positions of the attachments of the sugar and acyl groups were determined based on 2D COSY and NOESY experiment. The NOESY experiment revealed NOEs between H-1 of Glc A and H-4(δ8.85) of pelargonidin, H-1 of Glc B and H-6(δ7.03) of pelargonidin, and H-2(δ3.98) of Glc A and H-1 of Xyl ( Fig. 4 ), supporting the glycosylation of the C-3 and C-5 pelargonidin hydroxylgroups with Glc A and Glc B, respectively, while also indicating a sambubiose structure between Glc A and Xyl. Two characteristic down field shifted proton signals were assigned to the methylene protons of Glc A (δ4.33 and 4.43, H-6a and b), indicating acylation of the OH-6 of Glc A with p -coumaric acid ( I ). In the HMBC spectrum, correlation were detected between the anomeric proton of Glc A and C-3 carbone (δ 144.2) of pelargonidin, the anomeric proton of Glc B and C-5 carbon (δ 155.5) of pelargonidin, the anomeric proton of Xyl and C-2 carbone (δ 79.9) of Glc A, and methane proton of H-2 of Glc A and C-1 carbone (δ 104.5) of Xyl, which confirmes the glycosylation groups at OH-3 (pelargonidin), OH-5 (pelargonidin), OH-2 (Glc A), and OH-1 (Xyl) as Glc A, Glc B, Xyl, and Glc A, respectively ( Fig. 4 ). Consequently, the structure of pigment 7 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside), ( Fig. 4 , Fig. S2 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011).

sec.title: 2.2.2. Pigment 8
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 8 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 42 H 47 O 22 requires: 903.2559. Found: 903.2556. This value indicated that pigment 8 was composed pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucoside with one additional residue of ferulic acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 8 was similar to that of pigment 7 , except that the signals of p -coumaric acid ( I ) were replaced by signals of ferulic acid ( I ). The three aromatic proton signals of ferulic acid ( I ) were observed at δ7.11 (H-2), 6.81 (H-5), and 7.04 (H-6) with large coupling constants ( J = 16.0 and 16.0 Hz) of olefinic proton signals (δ6.34 H-α and 7.41 H-β) indicating a trans -ferulic acid ( Table 2 ). From these results, pigment 8 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
- (β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-( trans -feruloyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside) ( Fig. 4 , Fig. S2 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This pigment has been tentatively identified as pelargonidin 3-feruroylsambubioside-5-glucoside in
Matthiola incana ( Saito et al., 1996 )
. However, NMR data for pelargonidin 3-feruroylsambubioside-5-glucoside have not been reported previously. Therefore, this is the first report of the structure determination of pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-( trans - feruloyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside) by 1 H and 13 C NMR .

sec.title: 2.2.3. Pigment 10
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 10 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 50 H 51 O 23 requires: 1019.2821. Found: 1019.2814. This value indicated that pigment 10 was composed of pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucoside with two additional residues of p -coumaric acid.

The 1 H NMR spectrum of pigment 10 was similar to that of pigment 7 except for the signals of Xyl and additional p -coumaric acid (III) moieties present in pigment 10 ( Table 2 ). The chemical shift (δ4.68) of H-2 to Xyl in pigment 10 resulted in a shift to a lower magnetic field than that of pigment 7 (δ3.08), indicating that pigment 10 was acylated with p -coumaric acid (III) at OH-2 of Xyl ( Fig. 4 ). Two p -coumaric acids ( I & III) exhibited large coupling constants ( J = 15.9 and 15.9 Hz at ( I ) and J = 15.9 and 15.9 Hz at (III)) of both olefinic proton signals, indicating that both p -coumaric acids have the trans configurations ( Table 2 ). In the HMBC spectrum, the correlation between the methine proton (δ4.68) of H-2 of Xyl and COOH carbon (δ166.3) of p -coumaric acid (III) was observed, establishing the acylation at C-2 OH of Xyl as p -coumaric acid (III) ( Fig. 4 ). Therefore, the structure of pigment 10 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
- ( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]-5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside) ( Fig. 4 , Fig. S2 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by measuring its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: 2.2.4. Pigment 9
sec.p: The elemental components of pigment 9 were confirmed by measuring its HR-FAB MS ; calc. for C 56 H 61 O 28 requires: 1181.3349. Found: 1181.3350. This value indicated that pigment 9 was composed pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucoside with one additional residue of glucose and two additional residues of p -coumaric acid.

The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of pigment 9 was similar to that of pigment 10 , except for the signals of Xyl and additional glucosyl (Glc F) present in pigment 10 ( Table 2 ). The chemical shift (δ3.74) of H-3 of Xyl in pigment 9 resulted in a shift to a lower magnetic field than seen in pigment 10 (δ3.46), indicating that pigment 9 was glucosylated with Glc F at OH-3 of Xyl ( Fig. 4 ). In the NOESY and HMBC spectra, the correlation between anomeric proton (δ4.34) of H-1 of Glc F was correlated to the signal of C-3 (δ83.9) carbone of Xyl in its HMBC spectrum, and to the signals of the H-3 proton (δ3.74) of Xyl in NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 4 ). Therefore, the structure of pigment 9 was determined to be pelargonidin 3-
O
-[2-
O
-(2-
O
-( trans -p -coumaroyl)-3-
O
-(β-glucopyranosyl)-β-xylopyranosyl)-6-
O
-( trans -p -coumaroyl)-β-glucopyranoside]- 5-
O
-(β-glucopyranoside) ( Fig. 4 , Fig. S2 ), which is a new anthocyanin in plants (
;
;
; Veitch and Grayer, 2008, 2011). This structure was confirmed further by measuring its 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p:
Anthocyanins in the form of acylated cyanidin glycosides have been isolated previously from the flowers of
Iberis
and
Erysimum
cultivars (
;
, 2016). In the present study, six acylated pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucosides and four acylated pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides (including 3-(3 X -glucosylsambubioside)-5-glucoside) were isolated from the red-purple flowers of
I. umbellata
cultivars and the red flowers of
E. × cheiri
cultivars.

The genera
Erysimum
,
Matthiola
,
Lobularia
,
Raphanus
, and
Iberis
have many cultivars, and they are popular horticultural plants of the Brassicaceae . Only a few investigated species seem to contain anthocyanins based on both cyanidin and pelargonidin, as such co-occurrence has only been reported from
Matthiola incana
(
,
; Tatsuzawa et al., 2012b),
Lobularia maritima
(
,
, 2010a, 2018), and
Raphanus sativus
(Tatsuzawa, 2016;
). In the present study, acylated pelargonidin glycosides were detected in two of the most popular brassicaceous floricultural species,
Iberis umbellata
and
Erysimum × cheiri
, which have previously been reported to contain acylated cyanidin glycosides (
;
, 2016). These two anthocyanin backbones, cyanidin and pelargonidin, differ by a hydroxyl substituent lacking in the B-ring of pelargonidin, resulting in a tendency to form magenta pigments for cyanidin and orange-red pigments from pelargonidin. The co-occurrence of these two anthocyanin backbones in both of these species makes it relevant to actively breed for flower color in these ornamental plants.

From a structural point of view, there are two typical anthocyanidin glycosides, namely anthocyanidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides (including 3-(3 X -glucosylsambubioside)-5-glucoside) and anthocyanidin 3- sophoroside-5-glucosides that have been reported in the Brassicaceae . The presence of acylated anthocyanidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides has been reported in the flowers of genera
Arabis ( Ito et al., 2013 )
,
Aubrieta (Tatsuzawa et al., 2012c)
,
Erysimum
(
, 2016),
Heliophila ( Saito et al., 2011 )
,
Hesperis (Tatsuzawa, 2012)
, Ionopusidium (Tatsuzawa et al., 2014),
Lobularia
(
,
, 2010a, 2018),
Lunaria ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2006 )
,
Malcolmia ( Tatsuzawa et al., 2008a )
,
Matthiola
(
,
; Tatsuzawa et al., 2012a), and
Orychophragmus ( Honda et al., 2005 )
( Table 3 ), and from the leaves and stems of genus
Arabidopsis
(
;
). Moreover, the presence of acylated anthocyanidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucosides has been reported in the flowers of genera
Iberis ( Saito et al., 2008 )
,
Moricandia
(Tatsuzawa et al., 2012b, 2013, 2015a, b), and
Raphanus
(Tatsuzawa, 2016;
) ( Table 3 ), from the roots of genus
Raphanus
(
;
;
;
,
;
;
;
, 2010b), and from the leaves and stems of genera
Brassica
(
;
;
,b;
;
;
;
;
) and
Sinapis ( Takeda et al., 1988 )
. Therefore, the floral anthocyanins of
E. × cheiri
are grouped in the former type (anthocyanidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucosides), while those of
I. umbellata
are grouped into the latter type (anthocyanidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucosides) ( Table 3 ).

With respect to the distribution of acylated anthocyanins in the flowers of the Brassicaceae , anthocyanidin 3-[2-(glucosyl or xylosyl)-6- ( trans-p -coumaroyl)-glucoside]-5-[6-(malonyl)-glucoside] have been reported as basic anthocyanin structures (
, 2014). Some of the genera have additional acyl residues in the basic structures or demalonylated basic structures ( Table 3 ). The genera
Iberis
,
Moricandia
,
Orychophragmus
, and
Ionopsidium
have an additional poly-acylated linear side chain in their basic structures. A poly-acylated linear side chain of
Iberis
anthocyanins was found at the OH-6 of Glc A (R5 of Table 3 ), which is similar to that found in
Ionopsidium
.
Iberis
and
Ionopsidium
have different basic structures, but they have a poly-acylated linear side chain at the same position in the basic anthocyanin structure. Demalonylated basic structures on OH-6 of Glc B (R7 of Table 3 ) have been identified in the flowers of
E. × cheiri
, similar to those found in the flowers of
L. maritima
. These plant cultivars are popular floricultural plants, which have been bred actively. However, malonylated anthocyanins, which are present in many other brassicaceous flowers, have not been identified as major anthocyanins in the flowers of
E. × cheiri
and
L. maritima
( Table 3 ). It is apparent that there are no simple correlations of the various types of substituents; ordering of species according to either a xylose or glucose residue in a characteristic position ( Table 3 ) did not reveal any other obvious co-varying substituent. Despite the extensive elucidation of flower pigment diversity in crucifers summarized here, the biological functions of the various substituents remains elusive.

sec.title: 4.1. General procedures
sec.p:
Thin layer chromatography ( TLC ) was conducted on cellulosecoated plastic sheets (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany ) using five mobile phases: BAW ( n -BuOH/HOAc/ H 2 O . 4:1:2, v/v/v), BuHCl ( n -BuOH/2N HCl, 1:1, v/v, upper layer), AHW (HOAc/HCl/ H 2 O , 15:3:82, v/v/v), 1% HCl for anthocyanins and organic acid, and BAW and ETN (EtOH/ NH 4 OH/ H 2 O , 16:1:3, v/v/v) for sugars with detection using UV light and the aniline hydrogen phthalate spray reagent (
).

Analytical high performance liquid chromatography ( HPLC ) was performed with a LC 10A system (Shimadzu Co. Ltd., Kyoto , Japan ) using a Waters C 18 (4.6 ϕ x 250 mm , Waters, Massachusetts , USA ) column at 40 ° C with a flow rate of 1 mL/min and monitoring at 530 nm for anthocyanins, monitoring at 315 nm for hydroxycinnamic acids and monitoring at 210 nm for malonic acid. The eluant was applied as a linear gradient elution for 40 min from 20 to 85% solvent B (1.5% H 3 PO 4 , 20% HOAc, 25% MeCN in H 2 O ) in solvent A (1.5% H 3 PO
4 in
H 2 O ) for anthocyanins and hydroxycinnamic acids. The other elution for malonic acid was applied as an isocratic elution of solvent A for 10 min (Tatsuzawa et al., 2009). UV –Vis spectra were recorded on an MPS-2450 (Shimadzu) in 0.1% HCl-MeOH (from 200 to 700 nm ).

High resolution FAB mass (FABMS) spectra were determined on a JEOL JMS–700 Mass spectrometer ( JEOL , Ltd.) operating in the positive ion mode using 1:1 mixture of dithiothreitol and 3-nitrobenzyl alcohol as a matrix. 1 H (400 MHz) and 13 C (100 MHz) NMR spectra were measured on a JEOL AL –400 NMR spectrometer ( JEOL , Ltd.) using CF 3 COOD– DMSO‑ d 6 (9:1) as a solvent. Chemical shifts are reported on the δ-scale from tetramethylsilane as the internal standard, and coupling constants ( J ) are in Hz.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant materials
sec.p:
Seeds of the red-purple flowers of
Iberis umbellata
L. ( Brassicaceae ) ‘Candycane Red’ and ‘Candycane Rose’ and
Erysimum × cheiri
(L.) Crantz ( Brassicaceae ) ‘Aurora’ were purchased from Murakami Seed Co., Ltd. ( Ibaraki , Japan ) and Mr. Fothergill's Seeds Ltd. ( Suffolk , UK ), respectively. Seeds of
I. umbellata
were sown in October 2009 and seeds of
E. cheiri
were sown in October 2016 . Plants were grown in a greenhouse at Iwate University ( E141° 14′ , N39° 71′). The flowers of
I. umbellata
with red-purple color [Red-Purple 66A (‘Candycane Red’) and Red-Purple 68B (‘Candycane Rose’) by Royal Horticultural Society (R. H .S.) Color Chart and chromaticity value; b*/a* = −0.07 (‘Candycane Red’) and −0.28 (‘Candycane Rose’)] were collected in June 2010 . Moreover, the flowers of
E. × cheiri
‘Aurora’ with a red color [Red 53 C by R. H .S. Color Chart and chromaticity value; b*/ a* = 0.15 (‘Aurora’)] were collected between April and May 2018 . These flowers were dried overnight at 45 ° C , and kept in a refrigerator at about 4 ° C until needed.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and purification of anthocyanins
sec.p:
Dried flowers of
I . umbellata ‘Candycane
Red’ ( ca . 100 g ) and
E. cheiri
‘Aurora’ ( ca . 50 g ) were immersed in 5% HOAc (10 L and 5 L), respectively, at room temperature for 5 h and extracted. The extracted pigments were purified by Diaion HP-20 ion exchange resins, (Mitsubishi Chemical's, Tokyo , Japan ) column (90 × 150 mm ) chromatography, paper chromatography, and preparative HPLC as described previously (
). Finally, the following six anthocyanins were obtained from
I. umbellata
: 1 ( ca . 10 mg ), 2 ( ca . 12 mg ), 3 ( ca . 13 mg ), 4 ( ca . 14 mg ), 5 ( ca. 16 mg ), and 6 ( ca . 10 mg ), and four anthocyanins were obtained from
E. cheiri
: 7 ( ca. 80 mg ), 8 ( ca. 5 mg ), 9 ( ca. 13 mg ), and 10 ( ca. 38 mg ).
Pg:pelargonidin, Cy:cyanidin, Dp:delphinidin, Pn:peonidin, 3-samb-5-glc:3-sambubioside-5-glucoside, 3-soph-5-glc:3-sophoroside-5-glucoside, HCA:hydroxycinnamic acid, Glc:glucose, Mal:malonic acid.

sec.title: 4.4. Alkaline hydrolysis
sec.p:
Purified pigments 1–6 of
I. umbellata
( ca . 1 mg each) and pigments 7–10 of
E. cheiri
( ca. 1 mg ) were dissolved in 2N NaOH (100 μL, respectively) using a degassed syringe to stir for 15 min. The solution then was acidified with 2N HCl (110 μL, respectively). The alkaline hydrolysates were analyzed immediately by HPLC . Pelargonidin 3-sophoroside-5-glucoside [ HPLC : t R (min) 13.3] from pigments 1–6 , 4-
O
-glucosyl- p -coumaric acid [ HPLC : t R (min) 7.6] from pigments 1–5 , and 4-
O
- glucosyl-ferulic acid [ HPLC : t R (min) 10.2)] from pigment 1 , ferulic acid [ HPLC : t R (min) 18.3] from pigments 3–6 and 8 , p -coumaric acid [ HPLC : t R (min) 14.9] from pigments 1 , 7 , 9 , and 10 , and pelargonidin 3-sambubioside-5-glucoside [ HPLC : t R (min) 16.0] from pigment 7 , 8 , and 10 were identified by HPLC analysis as described previously (
). Moreover, alkaline hydrolysis of pigment 9 resulted in another anthocyanin glycoside [ HPLC : t R (min) 16.8].

sec.title: 4.5. Partial acid hydrolysis
sec.p:
Pigments 1–6 (each 0.5 mg ) were each dissolved in 2N HCl (0.5 ml) and hydrolyzed by heating in a water bath ( ca . 90 ° C ) for 10 min. The partial hydrolysates were analyzed immediately by HPLC (
).

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2018.12.010.
